Risk Management Plan

Executive Summary

Gavilon Fertilizer, LLC

Wesley Rd. Creve Coeur, IL 61610



I.    The Facility Policy:



The Facility owner, management, and employees of Gavilon Fertilizer, LLC are 

committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia.  Local 

responders are encouraged to visit the Facility to gain first hand knowledge of the site. 

Employees are required to hold monthly safety meeting and include sections of the 

management plan in those meetings.  If an accidental release should occur, the facility is 

prepared to work with local fire departments, and authorities to mitigate any release, and 

to minimize the impact of a release on the population and environment.



II.   Facility Information:



The primary activity of the Facility is to provide agricultural fertilizer for the farming 

industry in the area.  Part of the fertilizer comes in the form of Anhydrous Ammonia.  

Ammonia is received, stored, and used for production of  liquid fertilizer solutions.  

Ammonia is an important source of nitrogen for agricultural crops.

 

The maximum quantity that can be stored in the stationary vessel is approximately 120,000 pounds. 

However, the facility has the capability of receiving ammonia via railcar and has therefore calculated

the worst case release quantity using the volume of ammonia typically stored in a railcar 

(approximately 134,000 pounds).  The typical method of receiving ammonia is by 

truck transport containing 40,000 pounds. The process is considered a batch process and 

is operated as required to satisfy customer demand.



II.  Accidental Release Prevention:

   

The Facility has an internal written emergency plan to us as a guidance. The Facility 

takes guidance from material published by the American National Standards Institute 

"Safety Requirements  for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia" K61.1, and 

Compressed Gas Association CGA G-2.  The Facility also has a Process Sa

fety  Program 

that dovetails the RMP. The Facility tries to minimize the amount of ammonia held or 

stored at the facility through management  judgment. The Facility continues to review 

and look for means to improve operating and best management practice to increase 

safety. The Facility is routinely inspected by the Illinois Department of Ag for                             

compliance to State ammonia regulations.



IV. The Five Year Accident History:

       

There have been no accidental releases of ammonia related to the operation of this facility 

in the past five years.  There have been no deaths, injuries, or significant property damage 

at the Facility.  To the best of our knowledge, no off-site deaths, injuries, evacuations, 

sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage has occurred due to the 

operation of this facility.
